elements.content: Three isostructural Ln-BTB frameworks (Ln = Eu (1), Dy (2), Yb (3)) were synthesized and structurally characterized, in which mononuclear and trinuclear [Ln3] units as nodes construct unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected 3D frameworks with (4·6·8)4(4·82)2(4·85)­(62·84)­(45·68·826·106) point symbol. The luminescent investigations revealed that compound 1 can sensitively and selectively detect Al3+, but comparably compound 2 could not detect Al3+ among various cations. More importantly, 1 as an Al3+ sensor can be reused at least five times, which represents the first recyclable metal organic framework (MOF)-supported Al3+ sensor. Additionally, magnetic investigations on 2 also were carried out, showing a single-molecule-magnet behavior.
elements.clean_text: Three isostructural Ln-BTB frameworks (Ln = Eu (1), Dy (2), Yb (3)) were synthesized and structurally characterized, in which mononuclear and trinuclear [Ln3] units as nodes construct unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected 3D frameworks with (4⋅6⋅8)4(4⋅82)2(4⋅85)(62⋅84)(45⋅68⋅826⋅106) point symbol. The luminescent investigations revealed that compound 1 can sensitively and selectively detect Al3+, but comparably compound 2 could not detect Al3+ among various cations. More importantly, 1 as an Al3+ sensor can be reused at least five times, which represents the first recyclable metal organic framework (MOF)-supported Al3+ sensor. Additionally, magnetic investigations on 2 also were carried out, showing a single-molecule-magnet behavior.

elements.content:
A Eu-MOF can selectively detect Al3+, and it is the first example of a regenerable MOF-based luminescent Al3+ sensor.

Introduction

Aluminum, the most abundant metallic element in the lithosphere, has been broadly used in daily life and industry. In the past decades, because of the abundant utilization of aluminum products and the corrosion of acid rain, increasingly, Al3+ ions are directly exposed to the environment, leading to the superfluous accumulation of Al3+ in food. Excess intake of Al3+ can damage the human nervous system to cause neurodegeneration, resulting in Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s syndrome, etc. Thus, the effective detection of Al3+ has attracted extensive attention, and several chemical sensors of Al3+ have been reported. However, as far as we know, just a few metal organic framework (MOF)-supported sensors of Al3+ have been investigated, displaying high selectivity and sensitivity, and the corrersponding recycle performance has not been reported. Actually, the recycle performance is an important parameter for chemical sensors, which can reduce the cost to make them more suitable for practical applications. Therefore, it is necessary to further explore novel MOF materials as recyclable sensors for detecting Al3+.
elements.clean_text:
A Eu-MOF can selectively detect Al3+, and it is the first example of a regenerable MOF-based luminescent Al3+ sensor.

Introduction

Aluminum, the most abundant metallic element in the lithosphere, has been broadly used in daily life and industry. In the past decades, because of the abundant utilization of aluminum products and the corrosion of acid rain, increasingly, Al3+ ions are directly exposed to the environment, leading to the superfluous accumulation of Al3+ in food. Excess intake of Al3+ can damage the human nervous system to cause neurodegeneration, resulting in Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's syndrome, etc. Thus, the effective detection of Al3+ has attracted extensive attention, and several chemical sensors of Al3+ have been reported. However, as far as we know, just a few metal organic framework (MOF)-supported sensors of Al3+ have been investigated, displaying high selectivity and sensitivity, and the corrersponding recycle performance has not been reported. Actually, the recycle performance is an important parameter for chemical sensors, which can reduce the cost to make them more suitable for practical applications. Therefore, it is necessary to further explore novel MOF materials as recyclable sensors for detecting Al3+.

elements.content: Among numerous MOF-supported sensors, lanthanide-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are receiving enormous interest due to their excellent optical properties through an “antenna effect”, such as large Stokes shifts and high color purity. Up to now, many investigations on Ln-MOFs-supported sensors have been carried out to detect Mg2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Fe3+, PO4 3–, acetone, explosive, etc., and they displayed high sensitivity and excellent stablitities and regeneration abilities. Inspired by these cases, we aimed to synthesize Ln-MOFs as recyclable sensors to detect Al3+.
elements.clean_text: Among numerous MOF-supported sensors, lanthanide-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are receiving enormous interest due to their excellent optical properties through an "antenna effect", such as large Stokes shifts and high color purity. Up to now, many investigations on Ln-MOFs-supported sensors have been carried out to detect Mg2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Fe3+, PO4 3-, acetone, explosive, etc., and they displayed high sensitivity and excellent stablitities and regeneration abilities. Inspired by these cases, we aimed to synthesize Ln-MOFs as recyclable sensors to detect Al3+.

elements.content: In this contribution, three Ln-MOFs, {[H3O]2[Eu2.5(BTB)3­(OAc)0.5­(H2O)3]·2DMA·2.5H2O} n (Ln = Eu (1), Dy (2), Yb (3)), were obtained based on a robust ligand, 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate (H3BTB, Figure S1), which can be described as an elongated trimesic acid (H3BTC) and can easily transfer energy to lanthanide luminescent centers. Both frameworks are isostructural, and the topology analysis of 1 using the program TOPOS shows a (3,4,10)-connected net of (4·6·8)4­(4·82)2(4·85)­(62·84)­(45·68·826·106) point symbol. The luminescent investigations revealed that compound 1 could sensitively and selectively detect Al3+, but 2 could not effectively distinguish the luminescence respone of guest cations. The recycle performance of 1 as an Al3+ sensor was further explored, indicating that 1 could be reused at least five times by a simple recycling method. As far as we know, 1 is the first recyclable MOF-supported Al3+ sensor. Additionally, magnetic investigations of 2 also were carried out, showing a single-molecule-magnet (SMM) behavior.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, three Ln-MOFs, {[H3O]2[Eu2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (Ln = Eu (1), Dy (2), Yb (3)), were obtained based on a robust ligand, 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate (H3BTB, Figure S1), which can be described as an elongated trimesic acid (H3BTC) and can easily transfer energy to lanthanide luminescent centers. Both frameworks are isostructural, and the topology analysis of 1 using the program TOPOS shows a (3,4,10)-connected net of (4⋅6⋅8)4(4⋅82)2(4⋅85)(62⋅84)(45⋅68⋅826⋅106) point symbol. The luminescent investigations revealed that compound 1 could sensitively and selectively detect Al3+, but 2 could not effectively distinguish the luminescence respone of guest cations. The recycle performance of 1 as an Al3+ sensor was further explored, indicating that 1 could be reused at least five times by a simple recycling method. As far as we know, 1 is the first recyclable MOF-supported Al3+ sensor. Additionally, magnetic investigations of 2 also were carried out, showing a single-molecule-magnet (SMM) behavior.

elements.content: Eu­(OAc)3·4H2O (0.15 mmol, 60.1 mg), 0.1 mmol of H3BTB (43.8 mg), and 0.4 mmol of LiOH·H2O (16.8 mg) in DMA (4 mL) and H2O (1 mL) were sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 130 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to room temperature at 2 °C/h under ambient conditions. The colorless block crystals were obtained and washed with DMA. Yield: 83%, based on Eu­(OAc)3·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 1: C 53.32, H 4.02, N 1.38. Found: C 53.47, H 4.18, N 1.32.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation of {[H3O]2[Eu2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (1)

Eu(OAc)3⋅4H2O (0.15 mmol, 60.1 mg), 0.1 mmol of H3BTB (43.8 mg), and 0.4 mmol of LiOH⋅H2O (16.8 mg) in DMA (4 mL) and H2O (1 mL) were sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 130 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to room temperature at 2 °C/h under ambient conditions. The colorless block crystals were obtained and washed with DMA. Yield: 83%, based on Eu(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 1: C 53.32, H 4.02, N 1.38. Found: C 53.47, H 4.18, N 1.32.

elements.content: Compound 2 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Dy­(OAc)3·4H2O was used to replace Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Dy­(OAc)3·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 2: C 52.63, H 3.97, N 1.36. Found: C 52.95, H 4.05, N 1.42.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[H3O]2[Dy2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (2)

Compound 2 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Dy(OAc)3⋅4H2O was used to replace Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Dy(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 2: C 52.63, H 3.97, N 1.36. Found: C 52.95, H 4.05, N 1.42.

elements.content: Compound 3 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O was used to replace Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 3: C 51.97, H 3.92, N 1.34. Found: C 51.87, H 4.07, N 1.38.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[H3O]2[Yb2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (3)

Compound 3 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O was used to replace Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 3: C 51.97, H 3.92, N 1.34. Found: C 51.87, H 4.07, N 1.38.

elements.content: Compounds 1, 2, and 3 were obtained with a solvothermal method. Structures analysis of compounds 1, 2, and 3 suggests that all of compounds are isostructural and crystallize in the orthorhombic system with space group Pbcm. Thus, compound 1 is selected as a representative example for a detailed description. As illustrated in , it comprises three building blocks: two distinct Eu3+ ions and one [Eu3] cluster. Both the eight-coordinated Eu3 and Eu4 have a distorted square antiprism geometry, which is achieved by two water molecules and six oxygen atoms from carboxyl. Eu2, Eu1, and Eu1a are connected in a trinuclear [Eu3] unit by carboxyl groups. Three distinct building blocks are connected by a BTB3– ligand in a 3D anionic framework, displaying 1D channels along the a direction with a diameter range from 3.28 to 6.55 Å, and the total potential void volume of open channels in compound 1 is about 39.6% as calculated by the PLATON program.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure

Compounds 1, 2, and 3 were obtained with a solvothermal method. Structures analysis of compounds 1, 2, and 3 suggests that all of compounds are isostructural and crystallize in the orthorhombic system with space group Pbcm. Thus, compound 1 is selected as a representative example for a detailed description. As illustrated in , it comprises three building blocks: two distinct Eu3+ ions and one [Eu3] cluster. Both the eight-coordinated Eu3 and Eu4 have a distorted square antiprism geometry, which is achieved by two water molecules and six oxygen atoms from carboxyl. Eu2, Eu1, and Eu1a are connected in a trinuclear [Eu3] unit by carboxyl groups. Three distinct building blocks are connected by a BTB3- ligand in a 3D anionic framework, displaying 1D channels along the a direction with a diameter range from 3.28 to 6.55 Å, and the total potential void volume of open channels in compound 1 is about 39.6% as calculated by the PLATON program.

elements.content: Coordination environments of Eu3+ ions and the 3D framework of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environments of Eu3+ ions and the 3D framework of compound 1.

elements.content: In terms of the topological structure, Eu3 and Eu4 are coordinated by four BTB3– anions; thus both of them are considered as 4-connected nodes. The [Eu3] unit is coordinated by 10 BTB3– anions; thus it can be regarded as a 10-connected node. Each BTB3– anion is linking three Eu nodes as a 3-connected node. On account of this simplification, the corresponding structure of compound 1 can be suggested as a unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected net of (4·6·8)4(4·82)2­(4·85)­(62·84)­(45·68·826·106) point symbol (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: In terms of the topological structure, Eu3 and Eu4 are coordinated by four BTB3- anions; thus both of them are considered as 4-connected nodes. The [Eu3] unit is coordinated by 10 BTB3- anions; thus it can be regarded as a 10-connected node. Each BTB3- anion is linking three Eu nodes as a 3-connected node. On account of this simplification, the corresponding structure of compound 1 can be suggested as a unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected net of (4⋅6⋅8)4(4⋅82)2(4⋅85)(62⋅84)(45⋅68⋅826⋅106) point symbol (Figure S2).

elements.content: To study the stability of 1, 2, and 3, thermogravimetric analyses were done under a N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figure S3, three isomorphous frameworks showed similar TGA curves; thus we chose compound 1 as a representative to discuss their stability. From room temperature to 265 °C, a weight loss of 15.33% can be observed, which corresponds to the encapsulated [H3O]+ cations, DMA, and H2O molecules (calcd 15.35%). Subsequently, a complicated weight above 265 °C was observed, possibly attributed to the collapse of the charge-imbalanced framework. Finally, compound 1 starts to decompose sharply above 521 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) and Powder X-ray Diffraction Analyses (PXRD)

To study the stability of 1, 2, and 3, thermogravimetric analyses were done under a N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figure S3, three isomorphous frameworks showed similar TGA curves; thus we chose compound 1 as a representative to discuss their stability. From room temperature to 265 °C, a weight loss of 15.33% can be observed, which corresponds to the encapsulated [H3O]+ cations, DMA, and H2O molecules (calcd 15.35%). Subsequently, a complicated weight above 265 °C was observed, possibly attributed to the collapse of the charge-imbalanced framework. Finally, compound 1 starts to decompose sharply above 521 °C.

elements.content:
The powder XRD diffractions of 1, 2, and 3 are shown in Figure S4, and the PXRD patterns are almost identical to the simulated one, indicating that compounds 1, 2, and 3 are pure phases.

Luminescent Behaviors and Sensing Properties

Under excitation at 295 nm, the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were measured and are recorded in Figure S5. For compound 1, the five characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ were observed at 538, 592, 614, 653, and 696 nm (Figure S5a), attributed to the transitions of 5D1 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) from Eu3+ ions, respectively. In terms of Eu3+ transition rules, Eu3+ ions with inversion center sites emit orange light due to the transitions of the magnetic dipole (5D0 → 7F1); on the other hand, Eu3+ ions with noninversion center sites emit red light, due to the transitions of the electric dipole (5D0 →7F2). Considering the transitions of 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F2 in compound 1, the stronger 5D0 → 7F2 transition clearly revealed that Eu3+ ions locate at noninversion centers, according to the structural analyses. In 2, two typical emission peaks of Dy3+ were observed, at 480 and 575 nm (), attributed to the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 transitions, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
The powder XRD diffractions of 1, 2, and 3 are shown in Figure S4, and the PXRD patterns are almost identical to the simulated one, indicating that compounds 1, 2, and 3 are pure phases.

Luminescent Behaviors and Sensing Properties

Under excitation at 295 nm, the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were measured and are recorded in Figure S5. For compound 1, the five characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ were observed at 538, 592, 614, 653, and 696 nm (Figure S5a), attributed to the transitions of 5D1 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) from Eu3+ ions, respectively. In terms of Eu3+ transition rules, Eu3+ ions with inversion center sites emit orange light due to the transitions of the magnetic dipole (5D0 → 7F1); on the other hand, Eu3+ ions with noninversion center sites emit red light, due to the transitions of the electric dipole (5D0 →7F2). Considering the transitions of 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F2 in compound 1, the stronger 5D0 → 7F2 transition clearly revealed that Eu3+ ions locate at noninversion centers, according to the structural analyses. In 2, two typical emission peaks of Dy3+ were observed, at 480 and 575 nm (), attributed to the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 transitions, respectively.

elements.content: To explore whether 1 can detect cations, 4 mg samples of 1 were ground and immersed in 4 mL of an M­(NO3) x dimethylformamide (DMF) solution (7 × 10–4 M) (M = Al3+, Li+, Na+, K+, Cs+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Ag+, Cr3+, Fe2+, Cu2+, Fe3+) for 5 min, forming a 1-M x+ suspension. Under the perturbation of guest cations, the luminescent intensity of the resultant suspensions was recorded, and only emission peaks at 614 nm are shown in a. Notably, most cations display a negligible influence on the emission or reduce the luminescence to some degree, while Al3+ almost quenches the luminescence, indicating that compound 1 can act as a promising chemical sensor of Al3+ among various cations. Additionally, there are always several types of cations in wastewater; it is therefore beneficial to explore the effect of mixed cations on the emission. The detailed experiments were described as follows: 4 mg of compound 1 was immersed in 4 mL of DMF solution with Al3+ and another cation (7 × 10–4 M) for 5 min, and the luminescence intensity of the resultant suspensions was measured and is recorded in b. The obvious quenching effect of Al3+ is not changed after introducing other cations, indicating that 1 can selectively sense Al3+ among the various cations.
elements.clean_text: To explore whether 1 can detect cations, 4 mg samples of 1 were ground and immersed in 4 mL of an M(NO3) x  dimethylformamide (DMF) solution (7 × 10-4 M) (M = Al3+, Li+, Na+, K+, Cs+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Ag+, Cr3+, Fe2+, Cu2+, Fe3+) for 5 min, forming a 1-M x+ suspension. Under the perturbation of guest cations, the luminescent intensity of the resultant suspensions was recorded, and only emission peaks at 614 nm are shown in a. Notably, most cations display a negligible influence on the emission or reduce the luminescence to some degree, while Al3+ almost quenches the luminescence, indicating that compound 1 can act as a promising chemical sensor of Al3+ among various cations. Additionally, there are always several types of cations in wastewater; it is therefore beneficial to explore the effect of mixed cations on the emission. The detailed experiments were described as follows: 4 mg of compound 1 was immersed in 4 mL of DMF solution with Al3+ and another cation (7 × 10-4 M) for 5 min, and the luminescence intensity of the resultant suspensions was measured and is recorded in b. The obvious quenching effect of Al3+ is not changed after introducing other cations, indicating that 1 can selectively sense Al3+ among the various cations.

elements.content: (a) Luminescence intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions (614 nm) of 1 in response to various cations (7 × 10–4 M) for 5 min. (b) Comparison of the luminescence intensity of 1 exposed to mixed cations (7 × 10–4 M).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Luminescence intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions (614 nm) of 1 in response to various cations (7 × 10-4 M) for 5 min. (b) Comparison of the luminescence intensity of 1 exposed to mixed cations (7 × 10-4 M).

elements.content: Similar luminescent investigations on compound 2 were also carried out, and the corresponding emission peaks (575 nm) were recorded. As shown in Figure S6, most cations still have a negligible effect on the emission. However, Cr3+ and Fe2+ reduced the emission more sharply, and Al3+, Fe3+, and Cu2+ almost quench the luminescence. Thus, compund 2 could not effectively distinguish the luminescence response of guest cations, indicating that compound 2 could not be considered as a promising chemical sensor for detecting Al3+ among the above cations.
elements.clean_text: Similar luminescent investigations on compound 2 were also carried out, and the corresponding emission peaks (575 nm) were recorded. As shown in Figure S6, most cations still have a negligible effect on the emission. However, Cr3+ and Fe2+ reduced the emission more sharply, and Al3+, Fe3+, and Cu2+ almost quench the luminescence. Thus, compund 2 could not effectively distinguish the luminescence response of guest cations, indicating that compound 2 could not be considered as a promising chemical sensor for detecting Al3+ among the above cations.

elements.content: Moreover, the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for detecting Al3+ was also investigated: 4 mg samples of 1 were ground and immersed in a series of concentrations of Al­(NO3)3 DMF solutions (1 × 10–4 to 7 × 10–4 M) for 5 min. As shown in , the luminescence intensity of samples of 1 gradually decreases as the Al3+ concentration increases, and the luminescence intensity almost completely quenches as Al3+ increases to 7 × 10–4 M. Additionally, the decrease of emission still could be observed clearly under a 10–4 M Al3+ DMF solution, revealing that the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for sensing Al3+ ions could reach 10–4 M. To further investigate the Al3+ concentration of the quenching effect on compound 1, the luminescence intensity (614 nm) versus Al3+ concentration was charted (Figure S7), which could not be linear fitted to the Stern–Volmer equation, indicating that the quenching mechanisms are caused not only by the dynamic quenching processes.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for detecting Al3+ was also investigated: 4 mg samples of 1 were ground and immersed in a series of concentrations of Al(NO3)3 DMF solutions (1 × 10-4 to 7 × 10-4 M) for 5 min. As shown in , the luminescence intensity of samples of 1 gradually decreases as the Al3+ concentration increases, and the luminescence intensity almost completely quenches as Al3+ increases to 7 × 10-4 M. Additionally, the decrease of emission still could be observed clearly under a 10-4 M Al3+ DMF solution, revealing that the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for sensing Al3+ ions could reach 10-4 M. To further investigate the Al3+ concentration of the quenching effect on compound 1, the luminescence intensity (614 nm) versus Al3+ concentration was charted (Figure S7), which could not be linear fitted to the Stern-Volmer equation, indicating that the quenching mechanisms are caused not only by the dynamic quenching processes.

elements.content: Liquid luminescent spectra of 1 as a result of with different concentrations of Al3+.
elements.clean_text: 3  Liquid luminescent spectra of 1 as a result of with different concentrations of Al3+.

elements.content: As is known, MOFs as chemical sensors are still not widely used in practical applications, due to their nonrecyclable performance and high cost. Therefore, the recycling performance of compound 1 as an Al3+ sensor was investigated. First, we attempted to simply wash 1-Al3+ by DMF, but the luminescence intensity did not recover to theh original level, possibly attributed to residual Al3+ in the framework of 1, which may originate from a small amount of H3O+ exchanged by Al3+. Then, we tried to exchange Al3+ by saturated KNO3 in DMF solution as follows: samples of 1-Al3+ were immersed in a saturated KNO3 DMF solution for 1 h to exchange Al3+, and the corresponding samples were measured by inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP) to confirm that no Al3+ remained in the framework (Table S2). Then, the treated samples were washed by DMF solution to remove K+ on the surface. The emission almost recovered to the original level after the K+-exchange process and washing by DMF. Similar recycling experiments were carried out five times; the PXRD and the luminescence intensity of the recycled samples still conform to those of the original 1 ( and Figure S8). The experimental results clearly reveal that compound 1 as an Al3+ sensor can be reused at least five times by a simple method, showing the promising practical applications. More significantly, to the best of our knowledge, 1 is the first MOF-supported recyclable Al3+ sensor.
elements.clean_text: As is known, MOFs as chemical sensors are still not widely used in practical applications, due to their nonrecyclable performance and high cost. Therefore, the recycling performance of compound 1 as an Al3+ sensor was investigated. First, we attempted to simply wash 1-Al3+ by DMF, but the luminescence intensity did not recover to theh original level, possibly attributed to residual Al3+ in the framework of 1, which may originate from a small amount of H3O+ exchanged by Al3+. Then, we tried to exchange Al3+ by saturated KNO3 in DMF solution as follows: samples of 1-Al3+ were immersed in a saturated KNO3 DMF solution for 1 h to exchange Al3+, and the corresponding samples were measured by inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP) to confirm that no Al3+ remained in the framework (Table S2). Then, the treated samples were washed by DMF solution to remove K+ on the surface. The emission almost recovered to the original level after the K+-exchange process and washing by DMF. Similar recycling experiments were carried out five times; the PXRD and the luminescence intensity of the recycled samples still conform to those of the original 1 ( and Figure S8). The experimental results clearly reveal that compound 1 as an Al3+ sensor can be reused at least five times by a simple method, showing the promising practical applications. More significantly, to the best of our knowledge, 1 is the first MOF-supported recyclable Al3+ sensor.

elements.content: Luminescence intensity (614 nm) of compound 1 during five recyclings.
elements.clean_text: 4  Luminescence intensity (614 nm) of compound 1 during five recyclings.

elements.content: In the next step, we attempted to explain the possible mechanism whereby the introduction of Al3+ decreased the luminescent intensity. Generally, luminescence quenching is always caused by one of the following reasons: the collapse of the framework, the collision interation between guest cations and the framework, or the unsuitable adsorption/transformation energy. First, the PXRD of 1-M x+ was measured and still accorded with that simulated for 1 (), suggesting that the 3D framework of 1 is still stable after introducing Al3+, and the luminescence quenching caused by Al3+ did not originate from the collapse of the framework. Second, the collision between Al3+ and the framework, namely, a dynamic process mechanism, would decrease the stability of the framework and dissipate the energy to reduce the emission. However, the luminescence intensity (614 nm) versus Al3+ concentration () could not be well fitted to the Stern–Volmer equation, suggesting that luminescence quenching is caused not only by the dynamic process mechanism. Third, the emission of compound 1 originates from the energy transformation between BTB3– and the Eu3+ center, and the BTB3– ligand with a conjugate system can efficiently absorb energy from the UV spectrum and transfer energy to Eu3+. Al3+ has no obvious photon absorption at 295 nm (excitation wavelength), indicating that introudced Al3+ has no significant influence on the energy absorption of the ligand. Therefore, it is likely that the introduction of Al3+ causes the excited states of BTB3– and Eu3+ to not match well, resulting in the lower energy transformation from BTB3– to Eu3+ and even quenching emission.
elements.clean_text: In the next step, we attempted to explain the possible mechanism whereby the introduction of Al3+ decreased the luminescent intensity. Generally, luminescence quenching is always caused by one of the following reasons: the collapse of the framework, the collision interation between guest cations and the framework, or the unsuitable adsorption/transformation energy. First, the PXRD of 1-M x+ was measured and still accorded with that simulated for 1 (), suggesting that the 3D framework of 1 is still stable after introducing Al3+, and the luminescence quenching caused by Al3+ did not originate from the collapse of the framework. Second, the collision between Al3+ and the framework, namely, a dynamic process mechanism, would decrease the stability of the framework and dissipate the energy to reduce the emission. However, the luminescence intensity (614 nm) versus Al3+ concentration () could not be well fitted to the Stern-Volmer equation, suggesting that luminescence quenching is caused not only by the dynamic process mechanism. Third, the emission of compound 1 originates from the energy transformation between BTB3- and the Eu3+ center, and the BTB3- ligand with a conjugate system can efficiently absorb energy from the UV spectrum and transfer energy to Eu3+. Al3+ has no obvious photon absorption at 295 nm (excitation wavelength), indicating that introudced Al3+ has no significant influence on the energy absorption of the ligand. Therefore, it is likely that the introduction of Al3+ causes the excited states of BTB3- and Eu3+ to not match well, resulting in the lower energy transformation from BTB3- to Eu3+ and even quenching emission.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of the microcrystalline samples of compound 2 were measured in a temperature range from 1.8 to 300 K and under a 1000 Oe field (). Generally, 2S+1L J states are derived from the split of the 4f n configuration due to the coexistence of spin–orbit coupling and interelectronic repulsion. Additionally, because of the influence of the weak crystal field perturbation, each 2S+1L J state would be split into Stark sublevels, and the thermal depopulation of these Stark sublevels would cause the χM T to gradually decrease with decreasing temperature. As shown in , the value of χM T for compound 2 is 35.18 cm3·K·mol–1 at 300 K, which is close to the calculated value of 35.43 cm3·K·mol–1 expected for two and a half noninteracting Dy3+ in the 6H15/2 ground state (g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the value of χM T decreases gradually to reach 26.69 cm3·K·mol–1 at 1.8 K; hence, the essence of the interaction between Dy3+ ions in compound 2 cannot be completely decided, since the χM T value decreases when the temperature is lowered.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of the microcrystalline samples of compound 2 were measured in a temperature range from 1.8 to 300 K and under a 1000 Oe field (). Generally, 2S+1L J  states are derived from the split of the 4f n  configuration due to the coexistence of spin-orbit coupling and interelectronic repulsion. Additionally, because of the influence of the weak crystal field perturbation, each 2S+1L J  state would be split into Stark sublevels, and the thermal depopulation of these Stark sublevels would cause the χM T to gradually decrease with decreasing temperature. As shown in , the value of χM T for compound 2 is 35.18 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 300 K, which is close to the calculated value of 35.43 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 expected for two and a half noninteracting Dy3+ in the 6H15/2 ground state (g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the value of χM T decreases gradually to reach 26.69 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 1.8 K; hence, the essence of the interaction between Dy3+ ions in compound 2 cannot be completely decided, since the χM T value decreases when the temperature is lowered.

elements.content: Graphs of χM T versus temperature for compound 2 under a 1000 Oe field. The inset graph is the field dependence of the magnetization at different temperatures of 2.
elements.clean_text: 5  Graphs of χM T versus temperature for compound 2 under a 1000 Oe field. The inset graph is the field dependence of the magnetization at different temperatures of 2.

elements.content: The investigations of the field dependence of the magnetization of compound 2 were collected in the temperature range 2–5 K, as shown in (inset). The magnetization exhibits a slow enhancement at low fields and does not reach saturation even at 7 T, probably due to the magnetic anisotropy and/or the lack of a well-defined ground state. The behaviors suggest that there is a low-lying excited state, which is further proved by the nonoverlapping of M versus H/T curves for 2.
elements.clean_text: The investigations of the field dependence of the magnetization of compound 2 were collected in the temperature range 2-5 K, as shown in  (inset). The magnetization exhibits a slow enhancement at low fields and does not reach saturation even at 7 T, probably due to the magnetic anisotropy and/or the lack of a well-defined ground state. The behaviors suggest that there is a low-lying excited state, which is further proved by the nonoverlapping of M versus H/T curves for 2.

elements.content: The investigations of the alternating current (ac) magnetic measurements on 2 were carried out to further explore the dynamics of magnetization ( and S10). The corresponding measurements were performed with a frequency range from 10 to 700 Hz under temperatures between 2 and 15 K. The out-of-phase (χ″) components of the ac magnetic susceptibilities display a clear frequency dependence signal for 2 (), suggesting the presence of SMM behaviors. However, the maxima in χ″ are not found until the temperature is below 2 K. Such results were frequently observed in a number of Dy SMM species. The magnitude of the M″ values in the measured region is less than 10% of χM′, which was observed in reported compounds.

The corresponding measurements were performed with a frequency range from 10 to 700 Hz under temperatures between 2 and 15 K. The out-of-phase (χ") components of the ac magnetic susceptibilities display a clear frequency dependence signal for 2 (), suggesting the presence of SMM behaviors. However, the maxima in χ" are not found until the temperature is below 2 K. Such results were frequently observed in a number of Dy SMM species. The magnitude of the M" values in the measured region is less than 10% of χM', which was observed in reported compounds.

elements.content: In summary, a novel Eu-BTB anionic framework was obtained and structurally characterized, showing a topology of a (3,4,10)-connected net of (4·6·8)4(4·82)2­(4·85)­(62·84)­(45·68·826·106) point symbol. The luminescent investigations suggested that 1 as a luminescent sensor can selectively and sensitively detect Al3+. More significantly, 1 is the first recyclable MOF-supported Al3+ sensor. The luminescent investigations on 2 were also carried out, but 2 could not be used as a chemical sensor to detect Al3+ among various cations. Additionally, magnetic investigations of 2 also were carried out, showing an SMM behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a novel Eu-BTB anionic framework was obtained and structurally characterized, showing a topology of a (3,4,10)-connected net of (4⋅6⋅8)4(4⋅82)2(4⋅85)(62⋅84)(45⋅68⋅826⋅106) point symbol. The luminescent investigations suggested that 1 as a luminescent sensor can selectively and sensitively detect Al3+. More significantly, 1 is the first recyclable MOF-supported Al3+ sensor. The luminescent investigations on 2 were also carried out, but 2 could not be used as a chemical sensor to detect Al3+ among various cations. Additionally, magnetic investigations of 2 also were carried out, showing an SMM behavior.

cln_elements.content:
Eu­(OAc)3·4H2O (0.15 mmol, 60.1 mg), 0.1 mmol of H3BTB (43.8 mg), and 0.4 mmol of LiOH·H2O (16.8 mg) in DMA (4 mL) and H2O (1 mL) were sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 130 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to room temperature at 2 °C/h under ambient conditions. The colorless block crystals were obtained and washed with DMA. Yield: 83%, based on Eu­(OAc)3·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 1: C 53.32, H 4.02, N 1.38. Found: C 53.47, H 4.18, N 1.32.

Preparation of {[H<sub>3</sub>O]<sub>2</sub>[Dy<sub>2.5</sub>(BTB)<sub>3</sub>(OAc)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2DMA·2.5H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Dy­(OAc)3·4H2O was used to replace Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Dy­(OAc)3·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 2: C 52.63, H 3.97, N 1.36. Found: C 52.95, H 4.05, N 1.42.

Preparation of {[H<sub>3</sub>O]<sub>2</sub>[Yb<sub>2.5</sub>(BTB)<sub>3</sub>(OAc)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2DMA·2.5H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O was used to replace Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Yb­(OAc)3·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 3: C 51.97, H 3.92, N 1.34. Found: C 51.87, H 4.07, N 1.38.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation of {[H3O]2[Eu2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (1)

Eu(OAc)3⋅4H2O (0.15 mmol, 60.1 mg), 0.1 mmol of H3BTB (43.8 mg), and 0.4 mmol of LiOH⋅H2O (16.8 mg) in DMA (4 mL) and H2O (1 mL) were sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 130 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to room temperature at 2 °C/h under ambient conditions. The colorless block crystals were obtained and washed with DMA. Yield: 83%, based on Eu(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 1: C 53.32, H 4.02, N 1.38. Found: C 53.47, H 4.18, N 1.32.

Preparation of {[H3O]2[Dy2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (2)

Compound 2 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Dy(OAc)3⋅4H2O was used to replace Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Dy(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 2: C 52.63, H 3.97, N 1.36. Found: C 52.95, H 4.05, N 1.42.

Preparation of {[H3O]2[Yb2.5(BTB)3(OAc)0.5(H2O)3]⋅2DMA⋅2.5H2O} n  (3)

Compound 3 was obtained in a similar way to compound 1 except that Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O was used to replace Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Yield: 81%, based on Yb(OAc)3⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for compound 3: C 51.97, H 3.92, N 1.34. Found: C 51.87, H 4.07, N 1.38.

cln_elements.content:
To study the stability of 1, 2, and 3, thermogravimetric analyses were done under a N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figure S3, three isomorphous frameworks showed similar TGA curves; thus we chose compound 1 as a representative to discuss their stability. From room temperature to 265 °C, a weight loss of 15.33% can be observed, which corresponds to the encapsulated [H3O]+ cations, DMA, and H2O molecules (calcd 15.35%). Subsequently, a complicated weight above 265 °C was observed, possibly attributed to the collapse of the charge-imbalanced framework. Finally, compound 1 starts to decompose sharply above 521 °C.

The powder XRD diffractions of 1, 2, and 3 are shown in Figure S4, and the PXRD patterns are almost identical to the simulated one, indicating that compounds 1, 2, and 3 are pure phases.

Luminescent Behaviors and Sensing Properties

Under excitation at 295 nm, the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were measured and are recorded in Figure S5. For compound 1, the five characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ were observed at 538, 592, 614, 653, and 696 nm (Figure S5a), attributed to the transitions of 5D1 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) from Eu3+ ions, respectively. In terms of Eu3+ transition rules, Eu3+ ions with inversion center sites emit orange light due to the transitions of the magnetic dipole (5D0 → 7F1); on the other hand, Eu3+ ions with noninversion center sites emit red light, due to the transitions of the electric dipole (5D0 →7F2). Considering the transitions of 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F2 in compound 1, the stronger 5D0 → 7F2 transition clearly revealed that Eu3+ ions locate at noninversion centers, according to the structural analyses. In 2, two typical emission peaks of Dy3+ were observed, at 480 and 575 nm (), attributed to the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 transitions, respectively.

Moreover, the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for detecting Al3+ was also investigated: 4 mg samples of 1 were ground and immersed in a series of concentrations of Al­(NO3)3 DMF solutions (1 × 10–4 to 7 × 10–4 M) for 5 min. As shown in , the luminescence intensity of samples of 1 gradually decreases as the Al3+ concentration increases, and the luminescence intensity almost completely quenches as Al3+ increases to 7 × 10–4 M. Additionally, the decrease of emission still could be observed clearly under a 10–4 M Al3+ DMF solution, revealing that the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for sensing Al3+ ions could reach 10–4 M. To further investigate the Al3+ concentration of the quenching effect on compound 1, the luminescence intensity (614 nm) versus Al3+ concentration was charted (Figure S7), which could not be linear fitted to the Stern–Volmer equation, indicating that the quenching mechanisms are caused not only by the dynamic quenching processes.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of the microcrystalline samples of compound 2 were measured in a temperature range from 1.8 to 300 K and under a 1000 Oe field (). Generally, 2S+1L J states are derived from the split of the 4f n configuration due to the coexistence of spin–orbit coupling and interelectronic repulsion. Additionally, because of the influence of the weak crystal field perturbation, each 2S+1L J state would be split into Stark sublevels, and the thermal depopulation of these Stark sublevels would cause the χM T to gradually decrease with decreasing temperature. As shown in , the value of χM T for compound 2 is 35.18 cm3·K·mol–1 at 300 K, which is close to the calculated value of 35.43 cm3·K·mol–1 expected for two and a half noninteracting Dy3+ in the 6H15/2 ground state (g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the value of χM T decreases gradually to reach 26.69 cm3·K·mol–1 at 1.8 K; hence, the essence of the interaction between Dy3+ ions in compound 2 cannot be completely decided, since the χM T value decreases when the temperature is lowered.

The investigations of the alternating current (ac) magnetic measurements on 2 were carried out to further explore the dynamics of magnetization ( and S10). The corresponding measurements were performed with a frequency range from 10 to 700 Hz under temperatures between 2 and 15 K. The out-of-phase (χ″) components of the ac magnetic susceptibilities display a clear frequency dependence signal for 2 (), suggesting the presence of SMM behaviors. However, the maxima in χ″ are not found until the temperature is below 2 K. Such results were frequently observed in a number of Dy SMM species. The magnitude of the M″ values in the measured region is less than 10% of χM′, which was observed in reported compounds.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) and Powder X-ray Diffraction Analyses (PXRD)

To study the stability of 1, 2, and 3, thermogravimetric analyses were done under a N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figure S3, three isomorphous frameworks showed similar TGA curves; thus we chose compound 1 as a representative to discuss their stability. From room temperature to 265 °C, a weight loss of 15.33% can be observed, which corresponds to the encapsulated [H3O]+ cations, DMA, and H2O molecules (calcd 15.35%). Subsequently, a complicated weight above 265 °C was observed, possibly attributed to the collapse of the charge-imbalanced framework. Finally, compound 1 starts to decompose sharply above 521 °C.

The powder XRD diffractions of 1, 2, and 3 are shown in Figure S4, and the PXRD patterns are almost identical to the simulated one, indicating that compounds 1, 2, and 3 are pure phases.

Luminescent Behaviors and Sensing Properties

Under excitation at 295 nm, the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were measured and are recorded in Figure S5. For compound 1, the five characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ were observed at 538, 592, 614, 653, and 696 nm (Figure S5a), attributed to the transitions of 5D1 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) from Eu3+ ions, respectively. In terms of Eu3+ transition rules, Eu3+ ions with inversion center sites emit orange light due to the transitions of the magnetic dipole (5D0 → 7F1); on the other hand, Eu3+ ions with noninversion center sites emit red light, due to the transitions of the electric dipole (5D0 →7F2). Considering the transitions of 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F2 in compound 1, the stronger 5D0 → 7F2 transition clearly revealed that Eu3+ ions locate at noninversion centers, according to the structural analyses. In 2, two typical emission peaks of Dy3+ were observed, at 480 and 575 nm (), attributed to the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2 and 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 transitions, respectively. 

Moreover, the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for detecting Al3+ was also investigated: 4 mg samples of 1 were ground and immersed in a series of concentrations of Al(NO3)3 DMF solutions (1 × 10-4 to 7 × 10-4 M) for 5 min. As shown in , the luminescence intensity of samples of 1 gradually decreases as the Al3+ concentration increases, and the luminescence intensity almost completely quenches as Al3+ increases to 7 × 10-4 M. Additionally, the decrease of emission still could be observed clearly under a 10-4 M Al3+ DMF solution, revealing that the detection limit of 1 as a chemical sensor for sensing Al3+ ions could reach 10-4 M. To further investigate the Al3+ concentration of the quenching effect on compound 1, the luminescence intensity (614 nm) versus Al3+ concentration was charted (Figure S7), which could not be linear fitted to the Stern-Volmer equation, indicating that the quenching mechanisms are caused not only by the dynamic quenching processes. 

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of the microcrystalline samples of compound 2 were measured in a temperature range from 1.8 to 300 K and under a 1000 Oe field (). Generally, 2S+1L J  states are derived from the split of the 4f n  configuration due to the coexistence of spin-orbit coupling and interelectronic repulsion. Additionally, because of the influence of the weak crystal field perturbation, each 2S+1L J  state would be split into Stark sublevels, and the thermal depopulation of these Stark sublevels would cause the χM T to gradually decrease with decreasing temperature. As shown in , the value of χM T for compound 2 is 35.18 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 300 K, which is close to the calculated value of 35.43 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 expected for two and a half noninteracting Dy3+ in the 6H15/2 ground state (g = 4/3). Upon cooling, the value of χM T decreases gradually to reach 26.69 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 1.8 K; hence, the essence of the interaction between Dy3+ ions in compound 2 cannot be completely decided, since the χM T value decreases when the temperature is lowered.

The investigations of the alternating current (ac) magnetic measurements on 2 were carried out to further explore the dynamics of magnetization ( and S10). The corresponding measurements were performed with a frequency range from 10 to 700 Hz under temperatures between 2 and 15 K. The out-of-phase (χ") components of the ac magnetic susceptibilities display a clear frequency dependence signal for 2 (), suggesting the presence of SMM behaviors. However, the maxima in χ" are not found until the temperature is below 2 K. Such results were frequently observed in a number of Dy SMM species. The magnitude of the M" values in the measured region is less than 10% of χM', which was observed in reported compounds.
